4.title: Case Study 4: Flawed vs Corrected Time-of-Day Weekly Sales Visualization
4.subtitle: Design ethics
4.description: Both charts show the same kebab-sales dataset. The first collapses seven days into averages and breaks encoding rules; the second keeps all 42 rows visible with a clean mapping.

flawed.label: Flawed chart
flawed.title: Misleading weekly donut
flawed.caption: Looks like a weekly distribution of kebab sales by city and time, but it collapses seven days into six slices and hides the city encoding in tiny labels.
flawed.chartTitle: Weekly kebab sales distribution (time × city, flawed)
flawed.chartDescription: Seven concentric rings (one per day) squeeze city × time-of-day totals into decorative slices. Warm colors still encode only time, while the legend pretends they stand for cities.

reasons.axis: Seven concentric rings imply a third dimension, but no scale or markings tell you which ring corresponds to which day.
reasons.colors: All slices share the same warm hues per time of day, so two cities become impossible to separate visually.
reasons.legend: Legend labels pretend the colors encode cities (plus an average) even though the palette actually encodes time.
reasons.order: Rings stack inner → outer without any labels for days, so the weekly progression is hidden behind decoration.
reasons.aggregation: Each slice shows a daily total but the donut squeezes six metrics into a single angle, so city and day values blur together.
reasons.mapping: Angles encode city × time, rings secretly encode days, and the legend claims something else—the visual channels contradict the data structure.

fixed.label: Fixed chart
fixed.title: Truthful panel lines
fixed.caption: Same data with honest scaling, distinct colors, and a calm layout. Every single row stays visible in one stacked SVG.
fixed.chartTitle: Daily kebab sales by city and time of day
fixed.chartDescription: Single SVG with three horizontal panels (Morning, Midday, Evening). Each panel has two lines (Berlin, Köln) over seven days, shared x-scale, independent y-scales.

reasons.baseline: Each panel keeps its own y-axis and grid, so peaks stay readable no matter the band.
reasons.palette: Lines reuse the same high-contrast viridis colors whether they encode cities or times of day.
reasons.legend: Legend copy matches the active encoding and updates automatically with the toggle.
reasons.structure: Toggle flips between time-stacked and city-stacked panels without changing data or scales.
reasons.fullData: All 42 daily values (2 cities × 3 times × 7 days) remain visible—only the grouping changes.
reasons.mapping: Shared day axis, independent y-scales, dots for each day, and no hidden aggregation tricks.
